review_title: If you value having park access more than a respectable paycheck
pros:
Ability to create magical experiences for guests and being entrusted with the tools and resources to find meaningful solutions and recovery without needing management approval for every small decision. 

Park access.
cons:
Low pay relative to the industry.

Due to so many cast members having decades of seniority, it is almost impossible, even after 3 years, to get any holidays off. So I hope you don't care about spending Christmas or Thanksgiving with your family. 

Corporate is so focused on making a huge profit that the policies that are rolled out end up forcing frontline cast members to violate fundamental values such as prioritizing creating happiness. 

Corporate and Line of business are so resistant to investing the small amount of money needed to fix things (like upgrading computers that are 10 years old and can't run the necessary software fast enough to serve guests well) and would rather just throw money at the guests who complain to make the problem go away than actually solve the problem. Which, ironically, in the long run, ends up being more costly. 

Also, even with excellent job performance, it can be incredibly slow to advance.

job_title: Account Executive in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
The people - smart, hard working, relatable. 

The product - Hulu and Disney are a must buy.
cons:
Prior to Disney, Hulu was a fun place to work with minimal friction in the day to day. Culture was a top priority and for the most part, everyone enjoyed working there. 

After Disney, morale is low and the culture has deteriorated. Benefits are being rolled back and comp is changing. Tons of friction in the day-to-day as we do not have the infrastructure needed to support growth, too many managers & corporate policies. Managers & HR can't keep up with backfilling employees who left, so the existing ones are strapped with way too much work - all from home. Back to work plan is vague and top leadership is lacking. Hulu used to be an inspiring place to work and now it's depressing.

review_title: A great time, a lot of sacrifice
pros: Fulfilling, fun, decent wage, organized company. Expectations are made clear, and reprimands are cut and dry.
cons: Hard to move up, mentally and physically taxing. Moving up is possible, but it's difficult. There are a lot of entry level jobs and fewer second, third+ tier jobs. The costumes are heavy, and the energy output it high. Over time, your body just deteriorates from the wear and tear. Due to labor shortages (even pre-pandemic), you are often over-scheduled. As full time, you should utilize your time off to take much-needed mental health days.

pros: Working for the biggest theme parks in the world can be incredibly rewarding. In any role you take on, whether it is in entertainment, guest relations, server, housekeeping... you make people happy. I have been with this company for over twenty years and a job is really what you make of it. Great coworkers can make your day; guests who come back over and over become family. If you come in with a positive, open attitude, you will have the time of your life. Health insurance and other benefits are also wonderful.
cons: Admittedly, it can be taxing. Your schedule may be all over the place at times, and you may have a lot of physical labor, depending on your position. Sometimes, guests can take their frustrations out on you. Remember that it’s what they’re dealing with, and not a reflection on yourself. Pay can be rough, especially if you are in the college program, but don’t let that deter you. The unions continuously do their best to increase wages and benefits. Nobody and no job is perfect, but I still feel I should give the company a five star review because the positive experiences have far outweighed the negative. This may not be the case for everyone, bad things can happen in any job. But if you give the company a chance, you’ll hopefully have more pros than cons, too.

review_title: Treated like garbage and dehumanizing (Boardwalk custodial)
pros: Their is no pros overall, Maybe the free tickets and that's it
cons: The management at the boardwalk resort treats their custodials like trash. They overworked you to death in the hot burning sun just for a small paycheck that is barely $300 a week. You get in trouble for stupid stuff like not smiling enough or something similar like that. The job was overwhelming and very difficult to keep up. Management expects you to clean up a whole resort by your self, but when the guest are trashing the place at a very fast rate that you will not be able to keep up and you will get in trouble for it. Even if I ask for help no ones help me but they expect me to help them in very difficult times but do not help me when I cannot keep up. One of the biggest cons I have with this company is a big language barrier you will have with your fellow co workers. Majority of your co-workers are Hatians who cannot speak the English language or speak very poor English which make things difficult. A lot of Hatians people like to self isolate themselves from other cultures so it is common to see the Hatians talking with their own only and not hanging out with the other cultures which leads to many problems that the company is current facing. Very racist culture this company has among the cast members. And the same thing for the Hispanic people. Their is not unity with your fellow cast members here. No one is their for each other when things get tuff at work. Just a typical selfish American work environment. Unfortunately I was terminated in the company before my 3 month probation period has ended as a new hire for a made up bs reason the management has made up.

review_title: Lots of Reorgs, but Good People and Work Life Balance
pros:
Good people who have worked at the company for 10, 20, 30+ years
Good work life balance with not a lot of expected overtime
Change of project if you want to work on different things
Company is in a big change mode with lots of modernization coming to the tech side 
As a female, I have never felt uncomfortable with my coworkers, never felt that I was treated differently or disrespected
cons:
Lots of reorganization in the company right now, bosses changing, groups changing, it seems never ending 
Each team is an island with little to no communication across to other teams, ideas are not shared and many tools are rebuilt over and over by different teams, very little company-wide collaboration
Huge company, can feel really lost at times
Pay is low in comparison to other big companies with tech positions 
There are a lot of contractors who are very awesome, very skilled - but this leads to a feeling like your team is not permanent and getting consistency in projects is very difficult

review_title: Now more corporate than ever, employees considered expendable
job_title: Executive Assistant and Coordinator in Burbank, CA
pros: I worked with a lot of nice people, executives and staff. Many have left thought. Disney now gives bereavement time for pets. I've heard from others in Walt Disney Imagineering it's the best division to work in. Company is very attuned to diversity. If you visit the lot, this will be obvious.
cons: I started at Disney in Burbank in 2001. The benefits were not as good as I had had at a consulting firm in Chicago, but they were close. Now there is $1500 deductible, $4,000 total employee payout. The pension was ended in 2012. If you're not young or from an Ivy League school, moving up is almost impossible. Raise is 2% per year. HR always sides with management, even when management breaks the law. Keep your head down. Never talk to HR unless it's something a serious as sexual or racial harassment. Many executives and staff in the film division are arrogant and try to push out new staff. The fun of decorating desks, celebrating birthdays, marriages, etc. is gone now. Holiday parties are gone. Disney store on lot closed. It feels like working in a mausoleum. Every new employee, even executives, start at 2 weeks’ vacation which you must accrue for first five years. Very behind corporate peers in benefits and flexibility. I would not work there now in 2021.

review_title: Hides behind a veil of innocence
pros: Silver pass to the parks
cons: Everything else. You're just another number to them. Don't be fooled by their cookie-cutter image. They're a greedy, blood thirsty corporation that couldn't care less about their employees. They live up to their stingy reputation with their lowest-in-market pay so you'll end up working for much less. It's always "Do as we say and nobody gets hurt" approach so employees don't feel valued or feel empowered to voice their opinions or concerns. Only the few elite at the top make the decisions that benefit only the few elite at the top. If you don't believe me, just read one of the many complaints made by Abigail Disney and the other articles that talk about their selfish internal practices. I've moved on to a much better company that treats their employees with respect with much better pay. Working here significantly magnified the mistreatment endured at Disney.

review_title: A company that has lost its way
pros:
- Disney mostly looks good on your resume to some people. 
- Good health care and other benefits
cons:
With Bob Chapek at the helm the company has turned its focus completely to profits. You will be treated like an easily replaceable cog in the wheel, reorganized at the drop of a hat and as the Parks people found out, moved across country without regard for your kids and family. 

If you chose to work here you WILL be reorganized within months of taking your job. I’ve been here a decade and been through more than 20 reorganizations. Leadership lacks vision to create an organizational plan and stick to it. 

Chapek is ripping the soul from this company.  He’s been slowly eliminating any fun employee benefits like employee celebrations (he doesn’t see them as contributing to the bottom line) and has been actively exploring eliminating the free Park pass employees receive. 

Recently hundreds of people in IT were demoted, their salaries reduced, bonuses eliminated simply to save money. Their jobs were still needed but profit margins needed shoring up. 

There is lip service paid to diversity but at the highest levels of the company nothing has changed.  Diversity efforts are underfunded and marginalized. 

If you chose to work here, be forewarned: there are active efforts to stop you from moving around the company. It even has a name: talent hoarding. Leaders will refuse to allow employees to move to new jobs. There is no commitment to enabling movement and promotion within the company. 

Don’t stay here more than a few years — you’re not getting promoted under the Chapek regime anyway — because the industry knows that Disney people tend to come out of here inflexible and damaged. 

Maybe once Chapek leaves things will get better. For now Chapek is only good for stockholders.

pros:
1. Pay - Excellent pay that included a competitive base, management bonus that averaged 20% every year, and long-term incentives that averaged 20-30% per year, vesting over 4 years. If you come in at a manager level or higher, the compensation can be huge. But, there is a price to pay for this type of package....see cons below. 

2. Brand - The Disney brand will get you mileage in your career. You will make some good connections, but also some bad ones...see below.
cons: Overall, DTCI is a toxic environment, with a few decent people mixed in. You will encounter nepotism. I witnessed interns getting promoted from intern to senior manager rapidly, while those who have been honestly working hard have been bypassed, simply because they did not suck up to their leaders or make the right friendships. You will not get promoted based on your skills or merit. You will also encounter various forms of being undermined by your peers, with a few exceptions. Sabotage of work, gossiping and spreading rumors, and back-stabbing are common. This is not a collaborative environment, it is COMPETITIVE. You will also encounter machiavellian types, narcissists, and bullies on a daily basis. If you have a soul, it will be crushed. If you're soulless, this is the place for you.

review_title: It is all about your location and your team.
job_title: Guest Experience Manager-Housekeeping in Orlando, FL
pros: If you are fortunate enough to get a good location and they look good team there is a lot of camaraderie that is built. The nature of the type of guests we get means that many people genuinely believe in the magic that Disney is selling. Because of this you are able to connect in a different way than in some other hospitality jobs. There is a true emotional connection to the characters and the environment. In terms of benefits the company does offer tuition reimbursement for leaders on a class by class basis, and for hourly cast members there is the aspire program. Cast members also get free entrances into the parks. However, even before Covid there were a lot of block out dates. Now with Covid there are even more, so this really shouldn’t be a deciding factor.
cons:
Once again, it absolutely depends on your location. I worked at several different locations and overall the first ones were amazing. However, my last location was absolutely terrible. There was absolutely no work life balance, it was a very toxic and very abusive work environment, there was no support for managers from upper leader ship. Quite literally everyone at that location was stressed out of their mind. It was not uncommon to see leaders crying in their cars or in their offices. Leader shifts are a minimum of 10 hours but usually more. So even though you are being paid for 40 hours, expect to work at least 55+. Growth and advancement potential is once again based on your location. Many locations are so understaffed that there is very little mentorship possible. The company itself does have many different programs/clubs that cast members can join to help network, but trying to find time to actually do this is next to impossible. There is a huge culture of overworking and it is very normalized. You are look down on if you do not willingly give extra all the time. There are many stories of Directors and other leaders who started at the bottom and work their way up, but many times you’ll find that they are the absolute worst leaders. They were amazing at their jobs in an hourly sense but have no idea how to be good leaders and instead continue to perpetuate extremely toxic environments.
In terms of entrances to the parks, especially now with Covid, it is extremely challenging for cast members to get in if they are not fully blocked out all together.People genuinely want to work hard for this company. But they do not want to be taken advantage of or abused any longer. A shift in the culture needs to happen. People want to feel that they are being invested in just as they are investing in the company.

If you speak another language, do not let anybody know. Disney does not pay any type of differential for this skill and they will take advantage of you for it. There is a language line that Disney pays for the cast members to use, but once it is found out that you are a native speaker, you will get more work and not be compensated fairly for it.

They do this because they don't want you to utilize tools that would make it a better work environment for you because it will make more work for them. They only care about themselves and how they look. They cut corners all the time all day everyday. Until a higher up comes around. Then they run around telling everyone to do everything right while upper management, OSHA, third party companies they have contracts with, etc are there. Right after everyone leaves everything goes back to cut corners and being a toxic and dangerous work environment. If you say anything they do and will retaliate against you. I finally had to resign after years of dealing with to much toxicity from this company that started to cause a decline in my mental health and physical health. I'm so much happier far away from them. They want cast members to be uniformed robots and do not allow individualization at all.

review_title: My full time employment offer was rescinded just weeks before I was to start at Disney.
pros:
Good brand name experience for your resume. 

Free park passes and discounts to hotels and merchandise.
cons:
My full time job offer was rescinded weeks before my start date. 

Right up to the very end, my job offer was confirmed to be secure by Disney multiple times throughout the pandemic.

So it came as a total shock to me when the offer was suddenly pulled right after I graduated from college this summer.

I learned the hard way that a signed employment offer from Disney doesn't mean much!

Unfortunately, my experience is far from unique as I have since learned that Disney has pulled many job offers over the last couple of months. 

I guess they are trying to cut costs drastically to make their earning numbers look better than expected to Wall Street during the pandemic.

What's also upsetting is that after pulling all these job offers, Disney found money to donate $5 million to "social causes". 

That $5 million could have been used to pay for the salaries of the poor grads whose offers were rescinded by Disney.

But I guess it's more important to Disney to maintain their public do good image than to keep their promises.

pros:
Free entry to Disney parks (blockout dates apply)
Limited guest passes 
Discounts on merchandise
Workers union
Tuition Reimbursment for up to 3 classes a semester (not 100% as advertised online)
cons:
Some of the worst management I have ever experienced, and I have worked in 3 different roles for the Disney company (Full Service Food & Beverage - Seater, Merchandise, and Lifeguard). I have never felt less like a human being than when working for Disney. Working at Disney is a constant reminder that you are nothing more than a number and your needs are the last thing on the company's list of priorities (unless it's a liability). I have never cried at work until I got this job. I have never been legitimately screamed at by another adult until I got this job. After 3 years and a college program with Disney I am nothing but let down. My love for Disney was once so strong and now it is dead. 

The Disney look guidelines have been improved a lot recently as we are allowed to show tattoos and more nail polish colors, but they are still extremely strict and are quite ambiguous which means your management team can choose to make your life easy or hard. In my experience I have been singled out and yelled at countlessly on my "unnatural" brown roots growing back from my heavily highlighted hair, which I never let grow past half an inch. I was told I needed to die my hair all one color and never show any signs of root growth or I would risk being fired from the company. 

Contacting anyone including managers, HR, or casting is made extremely difficult. usually, you have to wait on hold for 30+ minutes or your management never contacts you altogether. If you have questions or concerns do not expect them to be addressed easily. 

Expect to work relentless hours, sometimes being scheduled 14 hours or more for one shift with little regard to your schedule the previous or next day. This means you could be scheduled until 2 am and have a morning shift the next day and Disney would not bat an eye. Furthermore, you are not garunteed a fixed schedule so your days are changing week to week. On the flip side, if you are part time you are not garaunteed any hours and you could be left unscheduled for months on end with absolutely no warning. Technically you can also be "force-extended" at work which means when your shift is over you are required to stay longer (could be hours) without any prior notice because the staff is short. All of these senarios have happened to me and to many others that I know. 

On the park operation level it is nearly impossible to move up in the company, especially to anything substancial. Disney is constantly hiring managers from outside or from professional internships. I know many cast members whose career goal is to move up within the company and after 5+ years of work they have barely recieved any kind promotion.

If you do not like your role it takes an entire year to be eligable to transfer to something new and that is not garaunteed. You also need to maintain a near perfect record card for this to happen, which can be difficult considering if you clock in even 1 second late you will be pointed. In addition, there are no sick days so if you need to stay home you will be pointed regardless of reasoning. 
 
Backstage break rooms in some locations are absolutely disgusting I have seen the biggest roaches in these areas. There is limited lunch options offered on site and in my experience there is never more than a 45 minute break depending on shift length and location, which means leaving work for a lunch run is impossible so prepare to bring your own. 

The list goes on.

pros: Large company with lots of different fields to work in. Working for a large, widely known company has its perks when talking to people.
cons: In the DTCI part of the company, management is pretty awful. The leaders are very secretive about the decisions that they are making and will often not let anyone know about changes until it's too late to provide input. Many of these changes are also told to the larger group in meetings and nothing is ever written down so that the leaders have deniability (which they use whenever something goes wrong). When issues are brought up to management they quickly get defensive and sometimes outright hostile and threaten people's future in the company. The HR department for DTCI also leaves a lot to be desired as they are rarely visible or helpful.
